questions.question_text: How does SSO work with HSRP to minimize network disruptions?

comments.content:
SSO HSRP alters the behavior of HSRP when a device with redundant Route Processors (RPs) is configured for stateful switchover (SSO) redundancy mode. When an RP is active and the other RP is standby, SSO enables the standby RP to take over if the active RP fails.

The SSO HSRP feature enables the Cisco IOS HSRP subsystem software to detect that a standby RP is installed and the system is configured in SSO redundancy mode. Further, if the active RP fails, no change occurs to the HSRP group itself and traffic continues to be forwarded through the current active gateway device.

Reference: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipapp_fhrp/configuration/15-s/fhp-15-s-book/fhp-hsrp-sso.html

D is the correct answer.

C is referring to NSF Non-Stop Forwarding which can be implemented in addition to SSO

discussion.content: D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipapp_fhrp/configuration/xe-3s/fhp-xe-3s-book/fhp-hsrp-sso.pdf

This question is worded terrible. Is this accurate for D? "on the same device"? Isn't HSRP between two DIFFERENT devices, one active and the other standby? Failover occurs to the standby RP on a DIFFERENT device and then that device becomes active.

comments.content:
"SSO HSRP alters the behavior of HSRP when a device with redundant Route Processors (RPs) is configured for stateful switchover (SSO) redundancy mode. When an RP is active and the other RP is standby, SSO enables the standby RP to take over if the active RP fails."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipapp_fhrp/configuration/15-sy/fhp-15-sy-book/fhp-hsrp-sso.pdf

The answer is D.
SSO has nothing to do with the failover in case of link failure. That is all HSRP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When SSO is enabled on a Cisco router, the active and standby routers exchange state information periodically. In the event of a failure, the standby router assumes the role of the active router and begins forwarding traffic. This process is transparent to the network, and there is no interruption in service.

Specifically, when SSO is enabled with HSRP, the standby router maintains a synchronized copy of the active router's HSRP state information, including the virtual IP address and MAC address. If the active router fails, the standby router can immediately take over as the active HSRP router and continue forwarding traffic using the same virtual IP and MAC addresses.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. It ensures fast failover in the case of link failure.
D is correct

Stateful Switchover. Note: Do not use HSRP with Cisco Nonstop Forwarding with Stateful Switchover.

Correct Answer is "D"

SSO HSRP

SSO HSRP alters the behavior of HSRP when a device with redundant Route Processors (RPs) is configured for stateful switchover (SSO) redundancy mode. When an RP is active and the other RP is standby, SSO enables the standby RP to take over if the active RP fails.

With this functionality, HSRP SSO information is synchronized to the standby RP, allowing traffic that is sent using the HSRP virtual IP address to be continuously forwarded during a switchover without a loss of data or a path change. Additionally, if both RPs fail on the active HSRP device, then the standby HSRP device takes over as the active HSRP device.

The feature is enabled by default when the redundancy mode of operation is set to SSO.
D is good SSO with hsrp relates to RP redundancy not switch redundancy
C is description of Cisco NSF. D is correct description for Stateful Switchover.

comments.content: Yes, you are right.

choices.D: It enables HSRP to failover to the standby RP on the same device.
choices.C: It enables data forwarding along known routes following a switchover, while the routing protocol reconverges.
choices.B: It ensures fast failover in the case of link failure.
choices.A: It enables HSRP to elect another switch in the group as the active HSRP switch.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which command when applied to the Atlanta router reduces type 3 LSA flooding into the backbone area and summarizes the inter-area routes on the Dallas router?

discussion.content:
OSPF is link state routing protocol that works on the concept of areas. All areas must have same LSDB (link state database); hence OSPF summarization can only done on the border routers i.e. on ABR (Area border router) and ASBR (Autonomous system boundary router).In this document we discussed about route summarization between the areas.

Background:
Summarization between areas can be done on ABR by using single command under OSPF process:

area [area-id] range [ ip-address ] [mask ] [advertise | not-advertise |cost {cost}]

A) area-id= Identifier of the area about which routes are to be summarized

B) [ ip-address ] [mask]= Summary route to be advertise in areas

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-documents/ospf-inter-area-route-summarization/ta-p/3145113

comments.content: Correct answer is D, I was wrong , this is a range not a filter, Imissed the key word , range is applied to source of the LSA, my apology.

discussion.content: Dallas is in Area 0, it's area 0 which is the backbone and prefixes that have to be summarized are in are 1, son it's 1->0 , LSA Type three summarization should be applied on ABR Atlanta indicating number of destination area: area 0, therefore neither B or D are correct

Selected Answer: D
We must configure a summarized route for Area 1 information and advertise it to the Dallas router to reduce LSA type 3 messages.

Atlanta(config)# router ospf <process ID>
Atlanta (config-router)# area 1 range 192.168.0.0 255.255.248.0

Network 192.168.0.0/22 with a SM 255.255.252.0 has the following:
Network IP: 192.168.0.0
First IP: 192.168.0.1
Last IP: 192.168.3.254
Broadcast IP: 192.168.3.255
It encompasses all the IP ranges for all the individual routes being advertised by Area 1 routers.

comments.content:
Correction: The answer is D because SM for /22 IP address is 255.255.248.0
The rest of the information above is correct.
Correction: SM for /22 IP address is 255.255.252.0 **
Note: OSFP can summarize routes only on ABRs and ASBRs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
We must configure a summarized route for Area 1 information and advertise it to the Dallas router to reduce LSA type 3 messages.

Atlanta(config)# router ospf <process ID>
Atlanta (config-router)# area 1 range 192.168.0.0 255.255.248.0

Network 192.168.0.0/22 with a SM 255.255.248.0 has the following: 
Network IP: 192.168.0.0
First IP: 192.168.0.1
Last IP: 192.168.3.254
Broadcast IP: 192.168.3.255
It encompasses all the IP ranges for all the individual routes being advertised by Area 1 routers.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
#area 1 range 192.168.0.0 255.255.252.0
it means advertise summary route FROM area 1 TO -> area 0
on the Dallas router, it will look like -> 192.168.0.0/22 (one instead four routes/24)

cisco_R3#show runn | s ospf

cisco_R3#

discussion.content: B and D would both do the job. But D is more of an exact match for those subnets, while B would allow those four subnets plus an additional four. I assume they're looking for answer D because it matches the subnet list exactly.

comments.content: B would break Area 0
i'm not really sure that it would since you'd have a more specific match as a connected route.. but that is specific to this particular topology
It might not break area 0, but the summarization would include the subnet that's in area 0: 192.168.4.0/24 (255.255.248.0 would include 192.168.0-7.0), so at the very least, bad practice.

discussion.content: This is route summarization the given answer is correct
The given answer is correct
D is good as it summarizes the best those 4 subnets 192.168.0/1/2/3.X
The correct answer is D.

questions.question_text:
An engineer must configure interface GigabitEthernet0/0 for VRRP group 10. When the router has the highest priority in the group, it must assume the master role.
Which command set must be added to the initial configuration to accomplish this task?

Initial Configuration -
interface GigabitEthernet0/0
description To IDF A 38-24-044.40
ip address 172.16.13.2 255.255.255.0

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is D

comments.content: For VRRP the commands always star with "VRRP"

Standby command is for HSRP
Standby "group" Word incorrect ----> Standby # ....

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Hi, VRRP enables preemption by default. So, i would put instead : vrrp 10 priority ..

comments.content:
Missing priority is probably a typo.
Preemption is default for VRRP so no need to add it.

The question doesn't say the router must have highest priority. It just says *when* it does, it must become master. That can only mean it needs the preempt command. Also the priority command in Option B is wrong because it doesn't have a priority number.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The virtual IP must be within the same subnet as the IP addresses of the physical interfaces on the routers participating in the HSRP or VRRP group.
HSRP uses 'standby 10 IP 172.16.13.254', and 'standby 10 preempt' commands, while VRRP uses a different set of commands 'VRRP 10 IP 172.16.12.254', and 'VRRP 10 preempt'.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

B is wrong, the question says when the router has the highest priority in the group, it must assume the master role, so we dont have to specify the priority.

And if we assume that B has 120 at the end, it will be wrong too, since "group" command is incorrect, and subnet mask should not be included in the VRRP configuration command.

There has got to be something wrong with this question because preempt is enabled by default on VRRP and there's no value listed for the priority which means everything is set to defaults. none of it makes any sense
Admins, please, these badly formatted questions needs to be fixed.

Selected Answer: D

 B. vrrp group 10 ip 172.16.13.254 255.255.255.0 vrrp group 10 priority (WRONG - word "group" is command in VRRP)

comments.content: Yes, you're right, I was kind of doubting my self and started asking how come, it is wrong
Exactly the solution provided looks wrong for these two points (they have mixed them)

That loop-free-alternate is an advanced feature and is not in-scope for this exam. By default OSPF will quickly run SPF algorithm and update the routing table. EIGRP does not compute the feasible successor after link failure. It computes it ahead of time (if it can) and has it ready for when the link fails.

discussion.content:
OSPF has a loop-free-alternate feature to maintain a backup path: 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/ip-routing/200225-Configure-Loop-Free-Alternate-path-with.html
EIGRP quickly computes a new route via the feasible successor, whereas OSPF may have to run the Dijkstra algorithm.
The given answer is correct
given answer is correct
given answers are right.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the characteristics from the left onto the routing protocols they describe on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
To configure DSW1 as the root bridge for VLANs 10 and 20 in spanning-tree instance '1', you can use either of the following commands:
- spanning-tree mst 1 priority 4096
This command sets the bridge priority for MST instance '1' to 4096. The bridge priority values range from 0 to 61440 and must be a multiple of 4096. A lower value indicates a higher priority for becoming the root bridge, thereby forcing DSW1 to be elected as the root switch for MST instance '1'.
- spanning-tree mst 1 root primary
This command designates DSW1 as the primary root bridge for MST instance '1'. It ensures DSW1 is elected as the root bridge regardless of its current MAC address or bridge priority.

Selected Answer: AB
A & B are correct

in Global config
(c)# spanning-tree instanceID# root {primary | secondary}
(c)# spanning-tree instanceID# priority {increment of 4096} default is 32768

Only time "vlan" is used is when you are configuring an instance in mst configuration
making choice E incorrect

comments.content:
Option D can't be because the priority should be increments of 4096 even though 0 can still apply, but not 1.
Option E can't be correct, because with MST the idea is to configure instances of VLANs, not VLANs individually and the command mstp doesn't seem to be a correct IOS command at all.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
The 2 ways to manipulate the configuration of the root bridge is by using the
 “spanning-tree mst instance-id priority value” command manually or the 
 “spanning-tree mst instance-id root ( primary | secondary )” command.
 If using the priority command you must set the ID in multiples of 4096.

always we have to put a number after mst
priority should be increment of 4096

always we have to put a number after mst , 
priority should be incrent 4096

mstp? Definitely not E.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which two commands ensure that DSW1 becomes the root bridge for VLAN 10 and 20? (Choose two.)
